auto_merge.commit_message:
Closes #5452

As described in PEP, a lot of the logic is moved into the tokenizer. So
we have a specialized f-fstring states covering the string part of the
fstring. When it hits a `{expr}` it goes into an `FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN`
which has enough logic to extract the expression into a string (to allow
self-documenting fstrings to work) but returns to the `fstring` state on
a suitable `:` or `}`.

I haven't updated `strip_string_literals` - the main issue I can see
with that is that it fails to identify the format specifier as string
literals

```
f'{a:cimport somemod}'
```

That's unlikely to be a useful format specifier, but would get
identified as a `cimport`. I'm ignoring this for now.

PR includes https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/7057 and the branch
https://github.com/cython/cython/compare/pep701_fstrings.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Closes #5452

As described in PEP, a lot of the logic is moved into the tokenizer. So we have a specialized f-fstring states covering the string part of the fstring. When it hits a `{expr}` it goes into an `FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN` which has enough logic to extract the expression into a string (to allow self-documenting fstrings to work) but returns to the `fstring` state on a suitable `:` or `}`.

I haven't updated `strip_string_literals` - the main issue I can see with that is that it fails to identify the format specifier as string literals

```
f'{a:cimport somemod}'
```

That's unlikely to be a useful format specifier, but would get identified as a `cimport`. I'm ignoring this for now.

PR includes https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/7057 and the branch https://github.com/cython/cython/compare/pep701_fstrings.

-------------------------------

I think most of the same thing gets reused for t-strings too so they're hopefully pretty simple to implement on top of this.

comment_data.body:
Just pushing code around here a bit, and I think we can reuse Method objects and don't have to recreate them on each iteration.
```suggestion
        unclosed_string_method = Method('unclosed_string_action')
        open_fstring_bracket_method = Method('open_fstring_bracket_action')
        close_fstring_bracket_method = Method('close_fstring_bracket_action')
        end_fstring_method = Method('end_fstring_action')

        for prefix in ["'", '"', "'''", '"""']:
            quote_type = 'SQ' if "'" in prefix else 'DQ'
            if len(prefix) > 1:
                triple = "T"
                newline_method = "NEWLINE"
                allowed_string_chars = Any("'\"")
            else:
                triple = ""
                newline_method = unclosed_string_method
                allowed_string_chars = Str('"' if quote_type == 'SQ' else "'")

            for raw in ["", "R"]:
                escapeseq_sy = rawescapeseq if raw else escapeseq
                out.append(
                    State(f"{triple}{type_}_{raw}FSTRING", [
                        (escapeseq_sy, 'ESCAPE'),
                        (Rep1(Str('{')), open_fstring_bracket_method),
                        (Rep1(Str('}')), close_fstring_bracketmethod),
                        (Rep1(AnyBut("'\"\n\\{}")), 'CHARS'),
                        (allowed_string_chars, 'CHARS'),
                        (Str("\n"), newline_method),
                        (Str(prefix), end_fstring_method),
                        (Eof, 'EOF')
                    ])
            )
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -86,6 +98,58 @@ def prefixed_digits(prefix, digits):
 
     comment = Str("#") + Rep(AnyBut("\n"))
 
+    def generate_fstring_states():
+        out = []
+
+        # In order for self-documenting strings to work, we need to
+        # pre-scan the fstring into a string, and then parse it
+        # again as an expression.  This allows us to accurately
+        # preserve whitespace (at the cost of repeatedly tokenizing
+        # for deeply nested fstrings).
+        # To do this we need to pay attention to brackets, strings,
+        # colons, and comments, but can ignore anything else.
+        out.append(
+            State("FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN", [
+                (Rep1(AnyBut('"\'{}()[]:#')), 'CHARS'),
+                (comment, IGNORE),
+                (Str(':'), Method('colon_action')),
+                (bra, Method('open_bracket_action')),
+                (ket, Method('close_bracket_action')),
+                (beginstring, Method('begin_string_action')),
+                (begin_fstring, Method('begin_fstring_action')),
+                (Eof, 'EOF')
+            ]))
+
+        for prefix in ["'", '"', "'''", '"""']:
+            if prefix[0] == "'":
+                type_ = 'SQ'
+                allowed_string_chars = Str('"')
+            else:
+                type_ = 'DQ'
+                allowed_string_chars = Str("'")
+            if len(prefix) > 1:
+                triple = "T"
+                newline_method = "NEWLINE"
+                allowed_string_chars = Any("'\"")
+            else:
+                triple = ""
+                newline_method = Method('unclosed_string_action')
+            for raw in ["", "R"]:
+                escapeseq_sy = rawescapeseq if raw else escapeseq
+                out.append(
+                    State(f"{triple}{type_}_{raw}FSTRING", [
+                        (escapeseq_sy, 'ESCAPE'),
+                        (Rep1(Str('{')), Method('open_fstring_bracket_action')),
+                        (Rep1(Str('}')), Method('close_fstring_bracket_action')),
+                        (Rep1(AnyBut("'\"\n\\{}")), 'CHARS'),
+                        (allowed_string_chars, 'CHARS'),
+                        (Str("\n"), newline_method),
+                        (Str(prefix), Method('end_fstring_action')),
+                        (Eof, 'EOF')
+                    ])
+            )

comment_data.body:
These don't look like they'd need to be `public`.
```suggestion
    # fstrings
    cdef list fstring_state_stack
    cdef int in_fstring_expr_prescan
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,6 +35,9 @@ cdef class PyrexScanner(Scanner):
     cdef public unicode sy
     cdef public systring  # EncodedString
     cdef public list put_back_on_failure
+    # fstrings
+    cdef public list fstring_state_stack
+    cdef public int in_fstring_expr_prescan

comment_data.body: We could name the states `SQ_STRING_F`, `SQ_STRING_FR`, etc. to avoid some of this string building. Then it'd only append suffixes to four static strings in f-string mode, and the state names would be easier to grep for.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -363,31 +366,100 @@ def open_bracket_action(self, text):
         return text
 
     def close_bracket_action(self, text):
+        if (text == '}' and self.fstring_state_stack and
+                self.fstring_state_stack[-1].bracket_nesting_level() == self.bracket_nesting_level):
+            if not self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
+                self.in_fstring_expr_prescan -= 1
+                if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan == 0:
+                    self.produce("END_FSTRING_EXPR")
+            self.begin(self.fstring_state_stack[-1].scanner_state)
+            self.fstring_state_stack[-1].pop_bracket_state()
         self.bracket_nesting_level -= 1
         return text
 
+    def colon_action(self, text):
+        if (self.fstring_state_stack and
+                self.fstring_state_stack[-1].bracket_nesting_level() == self.bracket_nesting_level):
+            self.in_fstring_expr_prescan -= 1
+            if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan == 0:
+                self.produce("END_FSTRING_EXPR")
+            self.begin(self.fstring_state_stack[-1].scanner_state)
+            self.fstring_state_stack[-1].set_in_format_specifier()
+        return text
+
     def newline_action(self, text):
         if self.bracket_nesting_level == 0:
             self.begin('INDENT')
             self.produce('NEWLINE', '')
 
     string_states = {
-        "'":   'SQ_STRING',
-        '"':   'DQ_STRING',
-        "'''": 'TSQ_STRING',
-        '"""': 'TDQ_STRING'
+        "'":   'SQ',
+        '"':   'DQ',
+        "'''": 'TSQ',
+        '"""': 'TDQ'
     }
 
     def begin_string_action(self, text: str):
         while text and text[0] in any_string_prefix:
             text = text[1:]
-        self.begin(self.string_states[text])
+        self.begin(f'{self.string_states[text]}_STRING')
         self.produce('BEGIN_STRING')
 
     def end_string_action(self, text):
-        self.begin('')
+        self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN' if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan else '')
         self.produce('END_STRING')
 
+    def begin_fstring_action(self, text):
+        is_raw = 'r' in text or 'R' in text
+        while text and (text[0] in any_string_prefix or text[0] in fstring_prefixes):
+            text = text[1:]
+        fstring_state = f'{self.string_states[text]}_{"R" if is_raw else ""}FSTRING'

comment_data.body: Do you think it's worth adding these to `Scanning.pxd` as cdef classes?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -571,3 +643,36 @@ def tentatively_scan(scanner: PyrexScanner):
             scanner.put_back_on_failure = put_back_on_failure
     finally:
         release_errors(ignore=True)
+
+
+class FStringState:
+    def __init__(self, scanner_state):
+        self.scanner_state = scanner_state
+        self.bracket_states = []
+
+    def bracket_nesting_level(self):
+        if not self.bracket_states:
+            return None
+        return self.bracket_states[-1].bracket_nesting_level
+
+    def in_format_specifier(self):
+        if not self.bracket_states:
+            return False
+        return self.bracket_states[-1].in_format_specifier
+
+    def set_in_format_specifier(self):
+        self.bracket_states[-1].in_format_specifier = True
+
+    def push_bracket_state(self, bracket_nesting_level: int):
+        self.bracket_states.append(FStringBracketState(bracket_nesting_level))
+
+    def pop_bracket_state(self):
+        self.bracket_states.pop()
+
+
+class FStringBracketState:
+    bracket_nesting_level: int
+    in_format_specifier: bool
+    def __init__(self, bracket_nesting_level: int):
+        self.bracket_nesting_level = bracket_nesting_level
+        self.in_format_specifier = False

@@ -363,31 +366,100 @@ def open_bracket_action(self, text):
         return text
 
     def close_bracket_action(self, text):
+        if (text == '}' and self.fstring_state_stack and
+                self.fstring_state_stack[-1].bracket_nesting_level() == self.bracket_nesting_level):
+            if not self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
+                self.in_fstring_expr_prescan -= 1
+                if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan == 0:
+                    self.produce("END_FSTRING_EXPR")
+            self.begin(self.fstring_state_stack[-1].scanner_state)
+            self.fstring_state_stack[-1].pop_bracket_state()
         self.bracket_nesting_level -= 1
         return text
 
+    def colon_action(self, text):
+        if (self.fstring_state_stack and
+                self.fstring_state_stack[-1].bracket_nesting_level() == self.bracket_nesting_level):
+            self.in_fstring_expr_prescan -= 1
+            if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan == 0:
+                self.produce("END_FSTRING_EXPR")
+            self.begin(self.fstring_state_stack[-1].scanner_state)
+            self.fstring_state_stack[-1].set_in_format_specifier()
+        return text
+
     def newline_action(self, text):
         if self.bracket_nesting_level == 0:
             self.begin('INDENT')
             self.produce('NEWLINE', '')
 
     string_states = {
-        "'":   'SQ_STRING',
-        '"':   'DQ_STRING',
-        "'''": 'TSQ_STRING',
-        '"""': 'TDQ_STRING'
+        "'":   'SQ',
+        '"':   'DQ',
+        "'''": 'TSQ',
+        '"""': 'TDQ'
     }
 
     def begin_string_action(self, text: str):
         while text and text[0] in any_string_prefix:
             text = text[1:]
-        self.begin(self.string_states[text])
+        self.begin(f'{self.string_states[text]}_STRING')
         self.produce('BEGIN_STRING')
 
     def end_string_action(self, text):
-        self.begin('')
+        self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN' if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan else '')
         self.produce('END_STRING')
 
+    def begin_fstring_action(self, text):
+        is_raw = 'r' in text or 'R' in text
+        while text and (text[0] in any_string_prefix or text[0] in fstring_prefixes):
+            text = text[1:]
+        fstring_state = f'{self.string_states[text]}_{"R" if is_raw else ""}FSTRING'
+        self.fstring_state_stack.append(
+            FStringState(fstring_state)
+        )
+        self.begin(fstring_state)
+        self.produce('BEGIN_FSTRING')
+
+    def end_fstring_action(self, text):
+        self.fstring_state_stack.pop()
+        self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN' if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan else '')
+        self.produce('END_FSTRING')
+
+    def open_fstring_bracket_action(self, text):
+        started_fstring_expr = False
+        while text:
+            if len(text) == 1 or self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
+                self.bracket_nesting_level += 1
+                if not started_fstring_expr:
+                    self.fstring_state_stack[-1].push_bracket_state(self.bracket_nesting_level)
+                    self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN')
+                    self.in_fstring_expr_prescan += 1
+                started_fstring_expr = True
+                self.produce(text[0])
+                text = text[1:]
+            else:
+                self.produce('CHARS', text[0])
+                text = text[2:]

comment_data.body: Do you think closing braces (`}`) are now special enough (compared to other brackets) to merit their own scanner action?

         return text
 
     def close_bracket_action(self, text):
+        if (text == '}' and self.fstring_state_stack and

comment_data.body:
I think we can directly disallow `rfr` here.
```suggestion
    begin_fstring = (
        ((Any(fstring_prefixes) + Opt(Any(raw_prefixes))) | (Opt(Any(raw_prefixes)) + Any(fstring_prefixes))) +
        (Str("'") | Str('"') | Str("'''") | Str('"""')))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -61,17 +62,28 @@ def prefixed_digits(prefix, digits):
     beginstring = Opt(Rep(Any(string_prefixes + raw_prefixes)) |
                       Any(char_prefixes)
                       ) + (Str("'") | Str('"') | Str("'''") | Str('"""'))
+    begin_fstring = (Opt(Any(raw_prefixes)) +
+                     Any(fstring_prefixes) +
+                     Opt(Any(raw_prefixes)) +
+                     (Str("'") | Str('"') | Str("'''") | Str('"""')))

comment_data.body:
This goes on my account, but it's a lot of code and processing just to say that you can combine `r` with anything, in any order, but no other characters with each other. We can probably get away with testing
`len(kind_string) == 1 or (len(kind_string) == 2 and kind_string.lower() in "rbrurfr")`
and just otherwise take our time (and possibly a separate function) to raise some kind of appropriate syntax error. That test should cover the normal cases quickly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -999,6 +1000,51 @@ def check_for_non_ascii_characters(string) -> cython.bint:
     return False
 
 
+@cython.cfunc
+def p_string_literal_shared_read(
+        s: PyrexScanner, pos, chars, kind,
+        is_raw: cython.bint, has_non_ascii_literal_characters: cython.bint):
+    """
+    Returns a tuple of (handled, has_non_ascii_literal_characters)
+    """
+    sy = s.sy
+    systr = cython.cast(str, s.systring)
+    is_python3_source: cython.bint = s.context.language_level >= 3
+    # print "p_string_literal: sy =", sy, repr(s.systring) ###
+    if sy == 'CHARS':
+        chars.append(systr)
+        if is_python3_source and not has_non_ascii_literal_characters and check_for_non_ascii_characters(systr):
+            has_non_ascii_literal_characters = True
+    elif sy == 'ESCAPE':
+        # in Py2, 'ur' raw unicode strings resolve unicode escapes but nothing else
+        if is_raw and (is_python3_source or kind != 'u' or len(systr) < 2 or systr[1] not in 'Uu'):
+            chars.append(systr)
+            if is_python3_source and not has_non_ascii_literal_characters and check_for_non_ascii_characters(systr):
+                has_non_ascii_literal_characters = True
+        else:
+            _append_escape_sequence(kind, chars, systr, s)
+    elif sy == 'NEWLINE':
+        chars.append('\n')
+    elif sy == 'EOF':
+        s.error("Unclosed string literal", pos=pos)
+    else:
+        return False, has_non_ascii_literal_characters
+    return True, has_non_ascii_literal_characters
+
+@cython.cfunc
+def _validate_kind_string(pos, systring: str):
+    kind_string = systring.rstrip('"\'').lower()
+    if len(kind_string) > 1:
+        if len(set(kind_string)) != len(kind_string):
+            error(pos, 'Duplicate string prefix character')
+        if 'b' in kind_string and 'u' in kind_string:
+            error(pos, 'String prefixes b and u cannot be combined')
+        if 'b' in kind_string and 'f' in kind_string:
+            error(pos, 'String prefixes b and f cannot be combined')
+        if 'u' in kind_string and 'f' in kind_string:
+            error(pos, 'String prefixes u and f cannot be combined')
+    return kind_string

comment_data.body: I always tried to avoid `cast()` because it's quite heavy in Python code. I don't think anything we do in this function is expensive enough to require `str` optimisations.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -999,6 +1000,51 @@ def check_for_non_ascii_characters(string) -> cython.bint:
     return False
 
 
+@cython.cfunc
+def p_string_literal_shared_read(
+        s: PyrexScanner, pos, chars, kind,
+        is_raw: cython.bint, has_non_ascii_literal_characters: cython.bint):
+    """
+    Returns a tuple of (handled, has_non_ascii_literal_characters)
+    """
+    sy = s.sy
+    systr = cython.cast(str, s.systring)

comment_data.body:
This seems the wrong place to determine `has_non_ascii_literal_characters`. It's passed in and out, there is only one caller that needs it, and that one can do the necessary checking itself. The new usage that you added is better off with a function that doesn't care about the flag.

Proposal: This function could return the plain characters to append (which could then be checked for non-ASCII characters if the caller is interested), and for escape sequences, it would append the resolved characters itself and return the empty string. If it does nothing, it can return None.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -999,6 +1000,51 @@ def check_for_non_ascii_characters(string) -> cython.bint:
     return False
 
 
+@cython.cfunc
+def p_string_literal_shared_read(
+        s: PyrexScanner, pos, chars, kind,
+        is_raw: cython.bint, has_non_ascii_literal_characters: cython.bint):
+    """
+    Returns a tuple of (handled, has_non_ascii_literal_characters)
+    """
+    sy = s.sy
+    systr = cython.cast(str, s.systring)
+    is_python3_source: cython.bint = s.context.language_level >= 3
+    # print "p_string_literal: sy =", sy, repr(s.systring) ###
+    if sy == 'CHARS':
+        chars.append(systr)
+        if is_python3_source and not has_non_ascii_literal_characters and check_for_non_ascii_characters(systr):
+            has_non_ascii_literal_characters = True
+    elif sy == 'ESCAPE':
+        # in Py2, 'ur' raw unicode strings resolve unicode escapes but nothing else
+        if is_raw and (is_python3_source or kind != 'u' or len(systr) < 2 or systr[1] not in 'Uu'):
+            chars.append(systr)
+            if is_python3_source and not has_non_ascii_literal_characters and check_for_non_ascii_characters(systr):
+                has_non_ascii_literal_characters = True

comment_data.body: Looking at the uses, probably only `FStringState`. I think all of the access to `FStringBracketState`  is done from list items, so it wouldn't get a lot (and you might just lose from boxing/unboxing). I might give `FStringBracketState` `__slots__` to try to keep it compact but there's probably no point in more.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -571,3 +643,36 @@ def tentatively_scan(scanner: PyrexScanner):
             scanner.put_back_on_failure = put_back_on_failure
     finally:
         release_errors(ignore=True)
+
+
+class FStringState:
+    def __init__(self, scanner_state):
+        self.scanner_state = scanner_state
+        self.bracket_states = []
+
+    def bracket_nesting_level(self):
+        if not self.bracket_states:
+            return None
+        return self.bracket_states[-1].bracket_nesting_level
+
+    def in_format_specifier(self):
+        if not self.bracket_states:
+            return False
+        return self.bracket_states[-1].in_format_specifier
+
+    def set_in_format_specifier(self):
+        self.bracket_states[-1].in_format_specifier = True
+
+    def push_bracket_state(self, bracket_nesting_level: int):
+        self.bracket_states.append(FStringBracketState(bracket_nesting_level))
+
+    def pop_bracket_state(self):
+        self.bracket_states.pop()
+
+
+class FStringBracketState:
+    bracket_nesting_level: int
+    in_format_specifier: bool
+    def __init__(self, bracket_nesting_level: int):
+        self.bracket_nesting_level = bracket_nesting_level
+        self.in_format_specifier = False

comment_data.body:
It's a bit awkward because essentially you're doing:
1. handle the first { if in the format specifier
2. Eat all the double {{s
3. Handle the last { if it exists

but I think I've got something workable

+        self.fstring_state_stack.pop()
+        self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN' if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan else '')
+        self.produce('END_FSTRING')
+
+    def open_fstring_bracket_action(self, text):
+        started_fstring_expr = False
+        while text:
+            if len(text) == 1 or self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
+                self.bracket_nesting_level += 1
+                if not started_fstring_expr:
+                    self.fstring_state_stack[-1].push_bracket_state(self.bracket_nesting_level)
+                    self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN')
+                    self.in_fstring_expr_prescan += 1
+                started_fstring_expr = True
+                self.produce(text[0])
+                text = text[1:]
+            else:
+                self.produce('CHARS', text[0])
+                text = text[2:]

comment_data.body:
I don't think this gets through the code style check unfortunately...

It's bad. But it is deliberate
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -683,3 +683,13 @@ def test_await_inside_f_string():
         print(f"{await f()}")
 
     print("PARSED_SUCCESSFULLY")
+
+
+# Be very careful allowing this test to be reformatted by an editor.
+# It deliberately contains tabs which should not be replaced with spaces.
+def test_print_self_documenting_tabs(x):
+    r"""
+    >>> test_print_self_documenting_tabs(5)
+    '\tx\t=5'
+    """
+    print(repr(f'{	x	=}'))

comment_data.body:
I think we only need the `Opt` once, that should remove a bit of ambiguity and potential backtracking.
```suggestion
        ((Any(fstring_prefixes) + Opt(Any(raw_prefixes))) | (Any(raw_prefixes) + Any(fstring_prefixes))) +
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -62,10 +62,9 @@ def prefixed_digits(prefix, digits):
     beginstring = Opt(Rep(Any(string_prefixes + raw_prefixes)) |
                       Any(char_prefixes)
                       ) + (Str("'") | Str('"') | Str("'''") | Str('"""'))
-    begin_fstring = (Opt(Any(raw_prefixes)) +
-                     Any(fstring_prefixes) +
-                     Opt(Any(raw_prefixes)) +
-                     (Str("'") | Str('"') | Str("'''") | Str('"""')))
+    begin_fstring = (
+        ((Any(fstring_prefixes) + Opt(Any(raw_prefixes))) | (Opt(Any(raw_prefixes)) + Any(fstring_prefixes))) +

comment_data.body:
Just an easy way to give a name to the bare `False` value without using a keyword argument.
```suggestion
        started_fstring_expr = False
        if self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
            self._handle_open_single_fstring_brace(started_fstring_expr)
            len_text -= 1
            started_fstring_expr = True
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -425,40 +433,61 @@ def end_fstring_action(self, text):
         self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN' if self.in_fstring_expr_prescan else '')
         self.produce('END_FSTRING')
 
-    def open_fstring_bracket_action(self, text):
-        started_fstring_expr = False
-        while text:
-            if len(text) == 1 or self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
-                self.bracket_nesting_level += 1
-                if not started_fstring_expr:
-                    self.fstring_state_stack[-1].push_bracket_state(self.bracket_nesting_level)
-                    self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN')
-                    self.in_fstring_expr_prescan += 1
-                started_fstring_expr = True
-                self.produce(text[0])
-                text = text[1:]
-            else:
-                self.produce('CHARS', text[0])
-                text = text[2:]
-
-    def close_fstring_bracket_action(self, text):
-        while text:
-            if len(text) == 1 or self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
-                fstring_bracket_level = self.fstring_state_stack[-1].bracket_nesting_level()
-                if fstring_bracket_level is None or self.bracket_nesting_level < fstring_bracket_level:
-                    # To help try to parse a little further, don't reduce the bracket
-                    # nesting level more.
-                    self.error(
-                        "f-string: single '}' is not allowed",
-                        pos=self.get_current_scan_pos(),
-                        fatal=False)
-                    self.produce('}', '}')
-                else:
-                    self.produce(self.close_bracket_action('}'), '}')
-                text = text[1:]
-            else:
-                self.produce('CHARS', text[0])
-                text = text[2:]
+    def _handle_open_single_fstring_brace(self, started_fstring_expr):
+        self.bracket_nesting_level += 1
+        if not started_fstring_expr:
+            self.fstring_state_stack[-1].push_bracket_state(self.bracket_nesting_level)
+            self.begin('FSTRING_EXPR_PRESCAN')
+            self.in_fstring_expr_prescan += 1
+        self.produce('{')
+
+    def open_fstring_brace_action(self, text):
+        len_text = len(text)
+        if self.fstring_state_stack[-1].in_format_specifier():
+            self._handle_open_single_fstring_brace(False)
+            len_text -= 1
+            started_fstring_expr = True
+        else:
+            started_fstring_expr = False

commit.message:
Update "test_fstrings.pyx" from CPython 3.13-pre.
Keeps out the "ast" related tests.

See https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5452
Fix bug with tokening apparent named character literals in raw string
Version that reads to an intermediate string
